physDesc.p: This letter consists of three typed pages on carbon paper and two certificates of issue inserted between pages two and three. The lower right corner of the first page is missing. On the first page there is an addressing heading in the upper left corner. On the upper right there is a dateline on each page, and after page one there is a header above the dateline (Mr. Aldington - 2).

div.p: You did not keep to your plan of writing to me every two weeks during my illness very well, did you? But I forgive you, I know how difficult it is to write when one gets no answer. What puzzles me a little more however is why you never sent me any of the clippings of the reviews of “Can Grande's Castle,” because, whatever their faults of comprehension may have been, they certainly gave me a great deal of space; even your “Times Literary Supplement” did that. Who wrote that article - do you know? Curiously enough, the most complimentary one of all came from the conservative old “Spectator.” I do think it is a little odd that you never mentioned them to me.

I am much better since my operation and have every hope that the doctors have at last cured me. I am not of course very strong as yet; although I have resumed my lectures I find that I have to be a little careful - too careful to make travelling very great fun at present, and I have decided not to come over this Spring. I may possibly turn up in the Autumn, but I rather think I shall wait for another year. The doctors seem to prefer it, and I am afraid of the cold in England after the Summer is over, since I feel the cold so much and am used to heated houses.

I have just given the centenary lecture on Keats at Yale, where I had such a jam that after putting chairs in the aisles and on the platform, they were obliged to hang a sign on the door to say that no more people could be admitted. This was rather a triumph, for our Universities are satiated with lecturers. I know that you do not care for Keats, and I do not know that I am as enthusiastic over his poetry as I used to be, but as a man I think [missing]
supremely interesting, and I have discovered so much unpublished material in my own collection and those of various other people here that I am embarking on a book about him, being my lecture expanded, which I hope to get done by the Autumn. I cannot imagine anything which you will sympathise with less than this, but I hope I can at least make it interesting to you.

I have got your friend Eliot's “Enchanted Wood,” which I think is well written but scarcely so original or epoch-making as you seem to think. I should be interested to meet Mr. Eliot sometime, though I am quite convinced that he disliked me. He sent the volume to my great friend, Professor John Lowel (sic), where I first saw it. It seems to me - let me whisper in your ear - a little antiquated in treatment, a bit pedantic and sententious, and for him to pick out dear old Professor Babbitt and that ancient fossil Paul Elmer More as the only American critics worthy of mention shows him to have left America a good while ago. Learning is an excellent thing, but it should be thoroughly digested. Well, I envy the learned however. How often I wish that I had been thoroughly grounded in something when I was young.

My new book of poems, “Legends,” is in the press and I suppose will be out in about six weeks. I will send you a copy when it comes out. I have no idea at all how “Can Grande” is going in England, but certainly Basil Blackwell succeeded in getting the papers to notice it. As far as agreeableness is concerned, he is certainly a most delightful publisher; I have never seen him personally.

I will not write any more now because I am trying very hard indeed to get some letters off before I return to New York for another lecture bout, to-morrow, but I have owed you a letter for so long that I feel guilty.
We must not let our correspondence lapse and so lose the thread for our next meeting.

I am enclosing a draft for 3.1 for the half-yearly royalties of the Imagist Anthologies. The account is as follows:
By sales: 27 Imagist Poets, 1915 .67-1/2 18.22
23 “ “ 1916 “ 15.52
22 “ “ 1917 “ 14.85
__
$48.59
1/6th of $48.59 is $8.09

They seem never to be going out of print. They have not been reprinted for a long time, but Ferris Greenslet writes me that the stock on hand consists of 98 copies of the 1915 anthology, with no sheets; 15 copies of the 1916, with 177 sheets; 80 copies of the 1917, with no sheets, so they ought to be finished up sometime.

postscript.label: P.S.
postscript.p: I am enclosing Flint's draft also, as I have no idea of his present address. I have not heard from him for ages. I wrote to him about his wife's death, as you suggested, but had no answer. 2 enclosures.
